Let's see...

What's the next big thing after large language models?
The technology of large language models--which

is essentially, we could take a piece 
of text, blank out some amount of it,

and then say what will the next word be, try and 
predict it, learn if you get it wrong and then

just repeat over billions of times.
You can take a picture and blank

out bits of it and try to predict 
what's in the part that's missing.

You can take a gene sequence and blank 
out a piece of it and try and predict it.

So, this is then a very successful strategy 
that can be used for all sorts of other

domains of human experience and science.
So we're going to see a lot of broader use

of foundation models in the soon nearby years.
Even though large language models have been

incredibly successful they don't really seem 
to build the kind of world models that human

beings have where they have a sense of stuff in 
a physical world and particular entities, human

beings and their relations that's more abstracted 
away from particular sequences of words.

And so that suggests we need some kind of 
different model of artificial intelligence.

But I think it's fair to say no one really knows 
the answer of how to do that successfully and so

that's why we're still doing academic research.
AI system asks what are some of the most promising

and exciting real world applications of NLP 
that you foresee emerging in the next few years?

Uh, tons! So I think we're going to see a lot 
more NLP systems being deployed very successfully

everywhere. So a lot of websites already have 
a little AI assistant in the bottom corner.

I think we're going to see a new generation 
of ones powered by large language models

which really work much more fluently.
I think we're going to see much more

use of conversational assistants. So, you're 
thinking about how to word an email to your

boss, or you're not quite sure what 
you should say to your boyfriend.

It turns out that you can 
get advice, drafting help,

suggestions of what to say from a large language 
model that are actually useful these days.

You know, I think there's just a whole world 
of ways that we can use these models because

our world is so language based and that we're 
all just sort of exploring what some of the possibilities are.

In the future will AI be so smart it won't need human input?
I think the honest answer is no one knows.

There is a conceivable world at some point in the 
distant future where an AI system can just learn

everything it needs needs from the world around it 
and it doesn't really need us to tell it things.

But I think there's also a lot of very heated 
hype at the moment. Some people think that by

2030 there'll be computers that are better 
than human beings at almost all tasks.

I think a lot of those views are fairly 
irrational exuberance where people have

been getting a little bit too excited by 
the very genuine big advances we made.

But there are other ways in which humans' 
knowledge and ability to operate in the

world is likely to be better than our AI 
models for a number of decades to come.

Will conversational assistants and 
chat bots replace search engines?

I think there are different answers for 
different kinds of searchers. So one

case is that people just have a particular 
question in mind like "when is the primary

going to be held in the election for California."
To the extent that I've got a question like that,

yeah absolutely, conversational agents 
LLMs are great for that sort of purpose,

then they're faster and better 
than something else you could use.

You can also use them for all kinds of 
other question-answering related purposes.

Sometimes people use search when they want 
to take a deep dive themselves, right.

You know, they're buying a new tent and 
they'd like to make up their own mind.

Then there's navigational queries 
where they just want to be taken

to the page and that's obviously not 
going to be covered by using a large language model.
